Line 27: Line 27:
The project was launched by Brian Brazil and Paul O'Malley in 2006. In October 2006, after the 0.85 release,<ref>[http://www.gnewsense.org/index.php?n=FAQ.FAQ#toc1 Release 0.85]</ref> it was given assistance by the [[Free Software Foundation]].<ref>[http://www.fsf.org/news/gnewsense gNewSense 1.0 released - Free Software Foundation]</ref>
The project was launched by Brian Brazil and Paul O'Malley in 2006. In October 2006, after the 0.85 release,<ref>[http://www.gnewsense.org/index.php?n=FAQ.FAQ#toc1 Release 0.85]</ref> it was given assistance by the [[Free Software Foundation]].<ref>[http://www.fsf.org/news/gnewsense gNewSense 1.0 released - Free Software Foundation]</ref>
â   â
== Comparison with Ubuntu ==
  â
Non-free software [[software repository|repositories]] are not provided by the gNewSense project, non-free documentation and artwork have been removed and Ubuntu's "Universe" package repository is enabled by default. In order to avoid [[trademark]] problems that stem from the modification of [[Mozilla Firefox]], gNewSense 1.1 rebranded it as "BurningDog". BurningDog likewise does not suggest [[non-free]] [[plugin]]s<ref>[http://www.gnewsense.org/Main/PressRelease20070122 gNewSense Official Website | Main / PressRelease20070122]</ref> for various web media, such as [[Adobe Flash]]. gNewSense 2.0 uses the [[Epiphany (browser)|Epiphany]] web browser as released by the [[GNOME]] Project, with an option in software sources to install [[Gnuzilla]] [[GNU IceCat|IceCat]]. Another contrasting distro is [[Super OS]], that with the goal of making things work "out of the box", includes non-free software and patent protected software, something people like [[Richard Stallman|R. Stallman]] criticize.
 
=== Limitations ===
=== Limitations ===
Over one hundred pieces of non-free [[firmware]] were removed from the Ubuntu [[Linux kernel]] to make gNewSense. Such removals include support for some [[wireless network]] cards, and therefore gNewSense currently supports a reduced range of wireless network cards compared to some other [[GNU/Linux distributions]]. 3D graphics and application support were also removed by May 1, 2008 <ref>http://www.gnewsense.org/Main/Deltah</ref> because of licensing issues<ref>[http://bugs.gnewsense.org/Bugs/00129]</ref> with [[Mesa 3D (OpenGL)|Mesa 3D]]. Since those issues were resolved on January 13, 2009, 3D support is now available again in the 2.2 release. <ref>http://www.fsf.org/blogs/licensing/2009-01-xorg-glx</ref>
Over one hundred pieces of non-free [[firmware]] were removed from the Ubuntu [[Linux kernel]] to make gNewSense. Such removals include support for some [[wireless network]] cards, and therefore gNewSense currently supports a reduced range of wireless network cards compared to some other [[GNU/Linux distributions]]. 3D graphics and application support were also removed by May 1, 2008 <ref>http://www.gnewsense.org/Main/Deltah</ref> because of licensing issues<ref>[http://bugs.gnewsense.org/Bugs/00129]</ref> with [[Mesa 3D (OpenGL)|Mesa 3D]]. Since those issues were resolved on January 13, 2009, 3D support is now available again in the 2.2 release. <ref>http://www.fsf.org/blogs/licensing/2009-01-xorg-glx</ref>
â   â
== Comparison with Debian ==
  â   â
[[Debian]] is another GNU/Linux distribution noted for strict licensing requirements. gNewSense excludes non-free software that Debian includes (such as non-free/proprietary [[firmware]]) and does not have repositories for non-free software (which Debian has). It should be noted, however, that gNewSense's policies allow including documentation that the Debian project considers non-free, particularly that licensed under the [[GNU Free Documentation License]] with invariant sections. This includes many manuals released by the [[GNU project]] themselves, which contain a lengthy manifesto promoting software freedom as an invariant section.
 
== Technical aspects ==
== Technical aspects ==
Line 61: Line 54:
Version 1.0, "deltad", was released on [[02 November]] [[2006]] and was based on Ubuntu 6.06 "Dapper Drake". Version 2.0, "deltah", followed on [[30 April]] [[2008]] and is based on Ubuntu 8.04 "Hardy Heron"; version 2.1 is a minor update which removes non-free software and expands hardware support.
Version 1.0, "deltad", was released on [[02 November]] [[2006]] and was based on Ubuntu 6.06 "Dapper Drake". Version 2.0, "deltah", followed on [[30 April]] [[2008]] and is based on Ubuntu 8.04 "Hardy Heron"; version 2.1 is a minor update which removes non-free software and expands hardware support.
  +   +
== Comparison with other distros ==
  +
Non-free software [[software repository|repositories]] are not provided by the gNewSense project, non-free documentation and artwork have been removed and Ubuntu's "Universe" package repository is enabled by default. In order to avoid [[trademark]] problems that stem from the modification of [[Mozilla Firefox]], gNewSense 1.1 rebranded it as "BurningDog". BurningDog likewise does not suggest [[non-free]] [[plugin]]s<ref>[http://www.gnewsense.org/Main/PressRelease20070122 gNewSense Official Website | Main / PressRelease20070122]</ref> for various web media, such as [[Adobe Flash]]. gNewSense 2.0 uses the [[Epiphany (browser)|Epiphany]] web browser as released by the [[GNOME]] Project, with an option in software sources to install [[Gnuzilla]] [[GNU IceCat|IceCat]]. [[Debian]] is another GNU/Linux distribution noted for strict licensing requirements. gNewSense excludes non-free software that Debian includes (such as non-free/proprietary [[firmware]]) and does not have repositories for non-free software (which Debian has). It should be noted, however, that gNewSense's policies allow including documentation that the Debian project considers non-free, particularly that licensed under the [[GNU Free Documentation License]] with invariant sections. This includes many manuals released by the [[GNU project]] themselves, which contain a lengthy manifesto promoting software freedom as an invariant section. Another contrasting distro is [[Super OS]], that with the goal of making things work "out of the box", includes non-free software and patent protected software, something people like [[Richard Stallman|R. Stallman]] criticize.
